1: <sup>1</sup> Lo, mine eye hath seen all this, mine ear hath heard and understood it.
2: <sup>2</sup> What ye know, the same do I know also: I am not inferior unto you.
3: <sup>3</sup> Surely I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.
4: <sup>4</sup> But ye are forgers of lies, ye are all physicians of no value.
5: <sup>5</sup> O that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom.
6: <sup>6</sup> Hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.
7: <sup>7</sup> Will ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?
8: <sup>8</sup> Will ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?
9: <sup>9</sup> Is it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye so mock him?
10: <sup>10</sup> He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.
11: <sup>11</sup> Shall not his excellency make you afraid? and his dread fall upon you?
12: <sup>12</sup> Your remembrances are like unto ashes, your bodies to bodies of clay.
13: <sup>13</sup> Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what will.
14: <sup>14</sup> Wherefore do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in mine hand?
15: <sup>15</sup> Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain mine own ways before him.
16: <sup>16</sup> He also shall be my salvation: for an hypocrite shall not come before him.
17: <sup>17</sup> Hear diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.
18: <sup>18</sup> Behold now, I have ordered my cause; I know that I shall be justified.
19: <sup>19</sup> Who is he that will plead with me? for now, if I hold my tongue, I shall give up the ghost.
20: <sup>20</sup> Only do not two things unto me: then will I not hide myself from thee.
21: <sup>21</sup> Withdraw thine hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid.
22: <sup>22</sup> Then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.
23: <sup>23</sup> How many are mine iniquities and sins? make me to know my transgression and my sin.
24: <sup>24</sup> Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and holdest me for thine enemy?
25: <sup>25</sup> Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
26: <sup>26</sup> For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth.
27: <sup>27</sup> Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly unto all my paths; thou settest a print upon the heels of my feet.
28: <sup>28</sup> And he, as a rotten thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth eaten.
